TopicTitle: What EVA operations would you like to see added?

Articles.Content: (For some reason, my heading is always my question ) The heading explains the question, what EVA operations would you like to see implemented. Personally, I would like to see something were you pick up a small fuel tank inside your ship, then fly outside to refuel some of the fuel tanks.

They've got pretty much all the EVA goodness I could think of more or less planned already. Collecting samples, repairing things, strut gun, rover party and sciency stuff. Hopefully there's a lot of EVA experiments you can do...not necessarily in the next patch, but at least eventually. Like ploppable experiments and things. Just stuff to do to make your landing sites look like you actually had purpose landing there.
Ship Maintanence, Sample Collecting, Dancing, Chattering, Drilling, Fixing
Repair, flipping rovers, transferring fuel to other Kerbals (I mean jet pack fuel.), and science
Carrying parts of spaceships or small ships.
Repairing solar panels and blowing stuff up

If you want to add a modicum of professionalism to your forum posts, this is all you need to know about formal writing:

TITLE

ABSTRACT

BODY

SUMMARY

The title is some flowery or catchy phrase which relates to the text. You might choose something like, "Advanced EVA Operations in Kerbal Space Program". In email and forum posts, you usually just take the subject from your title, which is why it's called 'subject', though the whole title is ok too.

SUBJECT: EVA Operations

The abstract is simply a statement of what the problem is or what the direction of the text is to take. Your posing a question for others to opine about, so your abstract is just that.

The body is where you present your evidence. In this case your own opinion on the question is your evidence.

The summary is a short rehash of the entire text. You can omit the summary, or it can replace the abstract and body.

Using your post as example:

What EVA operations would you like to see added?

[personally is redundant] I would like to see something w[h]ere you pick up a small fuel tank inside your ship, then fly outside to refuel some of the fuel tanks.

If you pick your title before you begin writing, you're likely to make your abstract the title. That's because it's natural to write the abstract first. If you write in this order:

ABSTRACT

SUMMARY

BODY

TITLE

Your title will come naturally from the text.

The purpose of this post is not to belittle. I hope you or others find it educational. It is also a reminder to myself to do a better job when writing for a public audience.
